exampleContent.title: Multiple Answers Examples
exampleContent.description: Learn how to identify and select multiple correct answers from a list of options
learningPoints: Read the question carefully to understand what you're looking for
Multiple answers can be correct - select ALL that apply
Look for common characteristics or patterns

sections.title: Identifying Multiple Correct Answers
sections.description: Learn strategies for finding all correct answers in multiple selection questions

examples.question: Which of the following are primary colors?
examples.explanation: The three primary colors are red, blue, and yellow. Green and purple are secondary colors made by mixing primary colors.
examples.strategy: Remember the basic color theory - primary colors cannot be created by mixing other colors.

examples.question: Which animals are mammals?
examples.explanation: Dogs, cats, and whales are all mammals. They are warm-blooded, have hair or fur, and feed milk to their babies.
examples.strategy: Think about the defining characteristics of mammals: warm-blooded, hair/fur, milk production.

sections.title: Category Recognition
sections.description: Practice identifying items that belong to specific categories

examples.question: Which of these are geometric shapes?
examples.explanation: Circle, square, and triangle are all geometric shapes. Apple and car are objects, not geometric shapes.
examples.strategy: Focus on the category being asked about and ignore items that don't fit.

exercises.question: Which of the following are fruits?
exercises.explanation: Apple, banana, and orange are fruits. Carrot and potato are vegetables.

exercises.question: Which numbers are even?
exercises.explanation: Even numbers are divisible by 2. The numbers 2, 8, and 20 are even. 3 and 15 are odd numbers.

exercises.question: Which of these are continents?
exercises.explanation: Asia, Europe, and Africa are continents. California and New York are states/cities, not continents.

exercises.question: Which of these activities require water?
exercises.explanation: Swimming, washing dishes, and cooking pasta all require water. Reading and sleeping do not need water.
